head.title: Help Doctors Who Help the Poor

hedline.hl1: Help Doctors Who Help the Poor

abstract.p: Prof Rebecca Dresser letter on July 30 article on cuts in loan program squeezing doctors who work with the poor; contends budgetary shortfalls are part of apparent Congressional trend to give more priority to research initiatives like Human Genome Project and less to programs giving patients access to available therapies

block.p: Re ''Cuts in Loan Program Squeeze Doctors Who Work With Poor'' (front page, July 30):

The budgetary shortfalls in this program are part of an apparent Congressional trend to give more priority to research initiatives like the Human Genome Project and less to programs giving patients access to available therapies.
Re ''Cuts in Loan Program Squeeze Doctors Who Work With Poor'' (front page, July 30):

The budgetary shortfalls in this program are part of an apparent Congressional trend to give more priority to research initiatives like the Human Genome Project and less to programs giving patients access to available therapies.

It is important for the government to support research to improve medical care for future patients. But the attraction of financing cutting-edge research should not overshadow the need to provide basic health services to patients today.
The writer is a professor of law and ethics in medicine at Washington University.
